definition: A pattern of dermatitis characterized by intercellular edema (spongiosis) between keratinocytes, stretching the intercellular bridges (desmosomes). It presents clinically as eczema.
clinical: Manifests as eczema (atopic, contact, nummular, dyshidrotic). Acute lesions are vesicular/weeping; subacute are scaly/crusted; chronic are thickened/lichenified.
pathogenesis: Complex immune response involving T-cells, Langerhans cells, and granulocytes releasing cytokines that cause fluid accumulation between keratinocytes.
macroscopic: Erythematous papules, plaques, vesicles (acute), or lichenification (chronic).
microscopic:
General: Spongiosis (intercellular edema) making spines/bridges prominent. 

Acute: Intraepidermal vesicles, Langerhans cell microgranulomas (flask-shaped collections), minimal acanthosis, basket-weave orthokeratosis (or serum accumulation). 

Subacute: Parakeratosis with serum ('wet scale'), irregular epidermal hyperplasia, variable spongiosis, superficial perivascular infiltrate (lymphs, eos). 

Chronic: Minimal spongiosis, marked epidermal hyperplasia (acanthosis), hypergranulosis, papillary dermal fibrosis (vertical collagen streaks), compact hyperkeratosis.
ancillary_studies:
IHC: S100 highlights Langerhans cells (dendritic cells, microgranulomas). 
Stains: PAS-D (serum is positive, must differentiate from hyphae). 
Experimental: IL-36 (stains intermediate/low in eczema vs high in psoriasis).
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis (dry scale/neutrophils, regular hyperplasia, thinned suprapapillary plates), Dermatophytosis, Mycosis Fungoides (Pautrier microabscesses), Viral exanthem (reticular degeneration).
prognosis_and_prediction: Benign inflammatory condition; chronic rubbing leads to Lichen Simplex Chronicus.

related_figures.legend: High power view showing intercellular bridges (spines) stretched by edema. (Time: 204s)
Development of intraepidermal vesicles due to marked spongiosis. (Time: 358s)
Langerhans cell microgranuloma (flask-shaped collection) within the epidermis. (Time: 496s)
S100 immunohistochemistry highlighting dendritic Langerhans cells. (Time: 697s)
Irregular epidermal hyperplasia with serum-containing parakeratosis ('wet scale'). (Time: 967s)
Minimal spongiosis, irregular hyperplasia, and early papillary dermal fibrosis. (Time: 1336s)
Pagetoid dyskeratosis (reactive pale keratinocytes) within the epidermis. (Time: 1455s)
Large intraepidermal vesicle with reticular strands of exudate. (Time: 1853s)

definition: A self-limiting papulosquamous eruption, often viral-associated, characterized by a herald patch and secondary eruption.
clinical: Herald patch followed by 'Christmas tree' distribution of scaly plaques. Common in children/young adults.
pathogenesis: Associated with HHV-6 and HHV-7 reactivation.
macroscopic: Oval, salmon-colored plaques with collarette of scale.
microscopic: Subacute spongiotic dermatitis with focal mounds of parakeratosis. Key feature: Extravasated erythrocytes in the papillary dermis and extending into the epidermis.

related_figures.legend: Spongiotic dermatitis with extravasated erythrocytes in the papillary dermis. (Time: 2157s)
Extravasated red blood cells within the epidermis. (Time: 2485s)

definition: A chronic form of spongiotic dermatitis occurring in areas rich in sebaceous glands.
clinical: Greasy scale/erythema on scalp, eyebrows, nasolabial folds, chest.
pathogenesis: Reaction to Malassezia yeast in sebum-rich areas.
macroscopic: Erythematous plaques with greasy yellow scale.
microscopic: Spongiosis often involving the follicular infundibulum (follicular spongiosis). 'Shoulder parakeratosis' (parakeratosis located at the lips of follicular ostia). Neutrophils may be present in the scale.
ancillary_studies: PAS may show yeast (Malassezia) in stratum corneum (though often sparse).
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis (scalp), Atopic Dermatitis, Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.

related_figures.legend: Spongiosis involving the follicular infundibulum. (Time: 2527s)
Shoulder parakeratosis around the follicular ostium. (Time: 2539s)

definition: Inflammatory dermatosis of the lower extremities secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.
clinical: Erythema, scale, hyperpigmentation, and edema on lower legs.
pathogenesis: Venous hypertension leads to capillary proliferation and extravasation of fluid/RBCs.
macroscopic: Varicose veins, pitting edema, brown discoloration (hemosiderin).
microscopic: Spongiosis with hypergranulosis and compact hyperkeratosis (acral-like features). Dermal changes: Lobular neovascularization (proliferation of small vessels) in papillary dermis, fibrosis, extravasated RBCs, and siderophages.
ancillary_studies: Perls (Iron) stain: Positive for hemosiderin (coarse golden-brown granules) in siderophages.
differential_diagnosis: Cellulitis, Contact Dermatitis, Pigmented Purpuric Dermatosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Persists with venous insufficiency; risk of ulceration.

related_figures.legend: Spongiosis with underlying neovascularization and fibrosis in the papillary dermis. (Time: 2586s)
Perls stain highlighting hemosiderin deposition. (Time: 2662s)
High power view of Perls stain showing coarse hemosiderin granules. (Time: 2727s)

definition: Fungal infection of the keratinized tissues (skin, hair, nails).
clinical: Annular scaly plaques (Tinea corporis), scale on feet (Tinea pedis).
microscopic: Spongiotic dermatitis. 'Sandwich sign' in stratum corneum (basket weave orthokeratosis -> parakeratosis with hyphae -> basket weave). Hyphae visible in stratum corneum.
ancillary_studies: PAS-D (Periodic Acid-Schiff with Diastase): Highlights fungal hyphae pink/red. Note: Serum is also PAS-D positive (potential pitfall).

related_figures.legend: Sandwich sign in stratum corneum: alternating basket weave and parakeratosis. (Time: 1263s)
PAS-D stain showing fungal hyphae within the stratum corneum. (Time: 1284s)
PAS-D positive serum collection (not fungus) - a potential diagnostic pitfall. (Time: 1229s)

definition: The pre-bullous or urticarial phase of bullous pemphigoid, presenting as eosinophilic spongiosis before frank blistering.
clinical: Pruritic urticarial plaques, often in elderly, preceding blister formation.
microscopic: Eosinophilic spongiosis (spongiosis with numerous eosinophils). Eosinophils lining up at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ) without frank subepidermal clefting yet.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone.
differential_diagnosis: Arthropod bite, Drug eruption, Incontinentia Pigmenti, Allergic Contact Dermatitis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Progresses to bullous phase if untreated.

related_figures.legend: Spongiosis overlying a dense eosinophilic infiltrate. (Time: 2878s)
Eosinophils lining up at the dermo-epidermal junction. (Time: 2886s)

definition: A severe cutaneous adverse reaction characterized by sterile pustules on an erythematous background.
clinical: Rapid onset of widespread non-follicular pustules, fever, leukocytosis.
microscopic: Spongiform pustules (neutrophils within spongiotic epidermis). Intraepidermal or subcorneal pustules. Edema in papillary dermis. Mixed infiltrate with neutrophils and eosinophils.
differential_diagnosis: Pustular Psoriasis (less spongiosis, more acanthosis), Infection.

related_figures.legend: Spongiotic reaction with vesicle formation containing neutrophils. (Time: 2862s)
Intraepidermal collection of neutrophils within a spongiotic vesicle. (Time: 2864s)
